entry.title: Combined summary - Comments on BOLT#11
entry.summary: A Node.js developer has implemented BOLT11 and shared it on Github, with the implementation still in progress. The developer suggests adding a tags_length integer before the first tag to detect poorly encoded data and recommends supporting full Unicode via UTF8 for descriptions, implementing a maximum length for descriptions, and recommending ways for parsing clients to fetch committed purpose description data to improve functionality and usability. Additionally, the developer's pull request for adding signature preimage hex data to examples is mentioned to help people writing decoders, but additional test cases for the RFC are suggested due to unclear language.The context also discusses the use of payment request descriptions in Lightning Network transactions. A member of the Lightning-dev mailing list suggests setting a reasonable maximum length for invoices that must be met and agrees with UTF-8 support and up to 640 bytes length. HTLC.me is one node that separates its balance into user accounts outside lightning and uses descriptions to join user data and payment hash on their end. However, descriptions are only meant to be displayed to the user and not used by the recipient, and Rusty Russell urges HTLC.me to fix the violation.In a forum post, Jonathan Underwood suggests a requirement be made to hide certain text in the description of payment requests under certain conditions. He proposes that information surrounded by curly brackets {} be hidden from the UI and only available internally. The use of UTF-8 encoding for descriptions in Bitcoin transactions is also discussed, with Underwood arguing that naive implementations that do not follow the UTF-8 spec should be mentioned to avoid mojibake corruption.The conversation between Rusty and Jon covers a range of topics related to the Lightning Network, including the decoding process, properly formatted signatures, clear descriptions of payments, the maximum field size allowed, and the potential de-anonymizing effects of including a URL in payment requests. They propose using HORNET as a solution and discuss the limitations of bech32 and the possibility of changing test vectors to JSON encoding.Lastly, the context includes a PGP public key block for secure communication with the developer, Athan Underwood, whose email address is associated with the key. This information is provided to facilitate secure communication between interested parties and the developer.
